title: Statistics & Probability
description: Covers 8-12% of the ACT. Master measures of center and spread, data representations (bar/line/scatter/histogram/box plots), two-way tables, probability, and counting techniques. Focus on fast and accurate graph reading.
goals: Calculate mean, median, mode, range, and weighted averages efficiently
Read and interpret graphs, scatter plots, histograms, and box plots
Extract information from two-way frequency tables and calculate conditional probabilities
Calculate basic, compound, and conditional probabilities
Apply the fundamental counting principle, permutations, and combinations
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release: concept-intro → I Do → We Do → You Do → mastery-check
AI uses scaffold array as scope and worked-example bank
Emphasis on graph-reading speed — ACT stat questions are often straightforward if you read carefully
Two-way tables taught as a dedicated topic since they appear frequently
Probability taught with emphasis on complementary probability (P(at least 1) = 1 - P(none))

scaffold.title: Measures of Center & Spread
scaffold.content: Statistics questions on the ACT are often easier than students expect — they just require careful reading. Mean, median, and weighted averages are the most common question types.
keyPoints: Mean (average) = sum of all values / number of values
Median = middle value when sorted. If even count, average the two middle values.
Mode = most frequently occurring value (can have multiple modes or no mode).
Range = maximum − minimum.
Weighted average: total = Σ(value × weight) / Σ(weights). Used for GPA, test averages with different point values, etc.
Standard deviation: measures spread from the mean. ACT only tests conceptual understanding (more spread = larger SD).
If you add a constant to every value: mean shifts by that constant, SD stays the same.

examples.problem:
A student scored 85, 92, 78, 95, and 90 on five tests. What is the mean score?
(A) 85  (B) 88  (C) 90  (D) 92  (E) 95

A class has 10 students who scored 80, and 20 students who scored 95. What is the class average?
(A) 85.0  (B) 87.5  (C) 88.0  (D) 90.0  (E) 92.5
examples.solution:
Weighted average: (10 × 80 + 20 × 95) / (10 + 20)
= (800 + 1900) / 30 = 2700 / 30 = 90
Answer: (D) 90.0

Trap: (B) 87.5 is the simple average of 80 and 95, ignoring the different group sizes.

Both sets have the same mean (50), but Set B's values are far more spread out.
Set A: values range from 48-52 (range = 4).
Set B: values range from 10-90 (range = 80).
Set B has much greater standard deviation.
Answer: (B) Set B

scaffold.title: Data Representations & Two-Way Tables
scaffold.content: The ACT loves graph-reading questions. The key is reading carefully — most errors come from misreading axes, labels, or scales. Two-way tables appear on nearly every ACT and are a dedicated question type.
keyPoints: Bar graphs: compare categories. Read values from the y-axis carefully.
Line graphs: show trends over time. Look for slope (rate of change).
Scatter plots: look for overall trend (positive, negative, none), outliers, and line of best fit.
Histograms: show frequency distribution. Each bar represents a range of values.
Box plots: minimum, Q1, median, Q3, maximum. IQR = Q3 − Q1.
Two-way tables: rows and columns represent two different categories. Totals in margins.
Conditional probability from table: P(A|B) = count in both A and B / total in B's row or column.
Always read axis labels and units FIRST before answering.

examples.problem:
A two-way table shows:

              | Cat | Dog | Total
    Male      |  12 |  18 |   30
    Female    |  20 |  15 |   35
    Total     |  32 |  33 |   65

What fraction of dog owners are male?
(A) 18/65  (B) 18/33  (C) 18/30  (D) 33/65  (E) 15/33
examples.solution:
Key phrase: 'of dog owners' → the denominator is the Dog column total (33).
Male dog owners = 18.
Fraction = 18/33.
Answer: (B) 18/33

Trap: (A) 18/65 uses the grand total. (C) 18/30 uses the Male row total.

examples.problem:
A box plot shows: min = 20, Q1 = 35, median = 50, Q3 = 65, max = 90. What is the IQR?
(A) 15  (B) 30  (C) 50  (D) 55  (E) 70
examples.solution:
IQR = Q3 − Q1 = 65 − 35 = 30
Answer: (B) 30

Note: IQR measures the spread of the middle 50% of the data.

examples.problem:
A scatter plot of study hours (x) vs. test scores (y) shows a strong positive trend. The line of best fit has equation y = 5x + 60. If a student studies 6 hours, what score does the model predict?
(A) 66  (B) 78  (C) 85  (D) 90  (E) 96
examples.solution:
Plug in x = 6: y = 5(6) + 60 = 30 + 60 = 90
Answer: (D) 90

Note: This is interpolation (within the data range), which is more reliable than extrapolation.

problems.problem:
The median of {3, 7, 12, 15, x, 25, 30} (already sorted) is 15. What are the possible values of x?
(A) x = 15  (B) x ≥ 15  (C) x ≤ 15  (D) 15 ≤ x ≤ 25  (E) Any value
hints: With 7 values, the median is the 4th value
For the 4th value to be 15, x must be ≥ 15 (to keep 15 in the 4th position)
problems.answer: (B) x ≥ 15. The 4th value in sorted order must be 15. If x < 15, x goes before 15 and shifts 15 to 5th position, making median = x or 15 depending on x. Actually: {3, 7, 12, 15, x, 25, 30} sorted — if x ≥ 15, median is 15. Answer: (D) 15 ≤ x ≤ 25.

problems.problem:
A class of 30 students has a mean test score of 82. If the teacher removes the lowest score of 40, what is the new mean?
(A) 82  (B) 83.0  (C) 83.4  (D) 84.0  (E) 84.6

Using the two-way table:

              | Yes | No | Total
    Seniors   |  25 | 15 |   40
    Juniors   |  30 | 30 |   60
    Total     |  55 | 45 |  100

What percent of Juniors said Yes?
(A) 30%  (B) 50%  (C) 55%  (D) 60%  (E) 75%
hints: Juniors who said Yes = 30, total Juniors = 60

scaffold.title: Probability & Counting
scaffold.content: Probability questions on the ACT range from basic to moderate difficulty. Counting questions appear less frequently but are easy points if you know the fundamental counting principle.
keyPoints: Basic probability: P(event) = favorable outcomes / total outcomes. Always between 0 and 1.
Complementary: P(not A) = 1 − P(A). Very useful for 'at least one' problems.
P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) − P(A and B). If mutually exclusive: just P(A) + P(B).
P(A and B) = P(A) × P(B) if independent. If dependent: P(A) × P(B|A).
Fundamental counting principle: if step 1 has m choices and step 2 has n choices → m × n total.
Permutations (order matters): nPr = n! / (n−r)!
Combinations (order doesn't matter): nCr = n! / [r!(n−r)!]
Decision rule: 'arrange/order' → permutation. 'Choose/select' → combination.

examples.problem:
A bag contains 3 red, 4 blue, and 5 green marbles. If one marble is drawn at random, what is the probability it is NOT green?
(A) 5/12  (B) 7/12  (C) 5/7  (D) 1/3  (E) 2/3
examples.solution:
Total marbles = 3 + 4 + 5 = 12.
P(green) = 5/12.
P(not green) = 1 − 5/12 = 7/12.
Answer: (B) 7/12

examples.problem:
Two dice are rolled. What is the probability that the sum is 7?
(A) 1/6  (B) 1/7  (C) 7/36  (D) 5/36  (E) 1/36

A password must be 3 characters: first a letter (26 choices), then a digit (10 choices), then a letter (26 choices). How many passwords are possible?
(A) 62  (B) 676  (C) 2,600  (D) 6,760  (E) 17,576

How many ways can a committee of 3 be chosen from 8 people?
(A) 24  (B) 56  (C) 120  (D) 336  (E) 512

problems.problem:
A coin is flipped 3 times. What is the probability of getting at least one head?
(A) 1/8  (B) 3/8  (C) 1/2  (D) 7/8  (E) 1
hints: Use complementary probability: P(at least 1 head) = 1 − P(no heads)

problems.problem:
A jar has 5 red and 3 blue marbles. Two marbles are drawn without replacement. What is the probability both are red?
(A) 5/14  (B) 25/64  (C) 5/8  (D) 10/28  (E) 15/56

In how many ways can 5 runners finish in first, second, and third place?
(A) 10  (B) 15  (C) 60  (D) 120  (E) 125

The mean of 5 numbers is 24. If one number (30) is removed, what is the mean of the remaining 4 numbers?
(A) 20  (B) 22.5  (C) 23.5  (D) 24  (E) 25.5

A histogram shows the following frequencies for test score ranges:
60-69: 3 students, 70-79: 7 students, 80-89: 12 students, 90-99: 8 students.
What percent of students scored 80 or above?
(A) 40%  (B) 60%  (C) 66.7%  (D) 73.3%  (E) 80%

From a standard deck of 52 cards, what is the probability of drawing a heart or a face card?
(A) 11/26  (B) 25/52  (C) 22/52  (D) 16/52  (E) 13/52
problems.answer: (C) 22/52. Hearts = 13. Face cards = 12. Heart face cards = 3. P = (13 + 12 − 3)/52 = 22/52 = 11/26.

problems.problem:
A 4-digit PIN uses digits 0-9. If no digit can be repeated, how many PINs are possible?
(A) 5,040  (B) 10,000  (C) 6,561  (D) 3,024  (E) 720

A box plot shows Q1 = 30, median = 45, Q3 = 60. Which statement MUST be true?
(A) The mean is 45  (B) 50% of data is between 30 and 60  (C) The range is 30  (D) No outliers exist  (E) The mode is 45
problems.answer: (B) 50% of data is between 30 and 60. By definition, Q1 to Q3 contains the middle 50% (IQR).

problems.problem:
In a survey, 60% of respondents like pizza, 40% like sushi, and 25% like both. What percent like pizza or sushi?
(A) 65%  (B) 75%  (C) 85%  (D) 100%  (E) 125%
